Free downloadable game of Football (Soccer) played on table top with paper figures or 25mm minatures. Turn based with 45 turns per half. Uses a D6 system where individual player stats and measurements decide failure or success on individual tests.
Create your own teams with included paper cut-out figs or 25mm figures available from the same company. Field is 40"x 60" and instructions are included to create your own pitch.

Name: U.S. MAIL and CHECKERS
Description:
Vintage (date unknown) board game where players spin and move along a pre-determined route on a map of North America. "The object of the game is to see which player can deliver Uncle Sam's mail the quickest and best."

This game comes in a cardboard box about 17" x 9" with a great graphic of a speeding steam engine pulled train on the lid. In the lower left corner of the top of the lid is the Milton Bradley name and the number 4904. No date is present on the box or the board.

The reverse of the game board is a yellow and black checker board.

Complete directions from box lid:

IMPLEMENTS consist of four differently colored pieces, one for each player (these represent mail trains), and an indicator. {Spinner}

THE OBJECT of the game is to see which player can deliver Uncle Sam's mail the quickest and best.

TO BEGIN. The players draw lots for first play. Then each player chooses as his starting point one of the four cities: New York, Chicago, new Orleans or San Francisco. No two players can start from the same city.

THE PLAY: Each player then puts his piece on the city of his choice and all spin the indicator {spinner} in turn. As soon as a "3" is spun, the player spinning it is entitles to start on his journey.
The player may travel in either direction.
Each circle, whether colored black, red, or green, counts as one space.
Each time a player's piece, or "mail train", falls exactly upon a green circle the player loses a turn.
Each time a player's "train" falls exactly upon a circle city which is colored red, the player counts one to his score.
No two players may occupy the same space. The last comer loses his turn.
The player first to reach the city he starts from counts five extra to his score.

TO WIN. The player scoring the most points wins.
Families: Theme: Mail / Stamps / The Post Office

Name: Ice Solo
Description:
A solitaire games using Icehouse/Treehouse pieces.  The original version involved starting with 60 pyramids (4 monochrome Icehouse "stashes") arranged in randomly-colored trees (small on medium on large) in a 5x4 grid.  The object to hop pieces to other stacks in the same row or column and end up with monochrome nests (large on medium on small).  Score is based on number and pattern of completed nests.

The original 5x4 game for four monochrome stashes can easily be extended to 5x5 to accommodate the pyramids that come with five Treehouse sets, which could also be considered a "Volcano set".  Also, a Volcano board makes Ice Solo just that much nicer.

This page quotes the original 5x4 rules and gives a little more info on the 5x5 version.

Name: Spanish Fury, Duel!
Description:
This is module number 7 of the Spanish Fury Renaissance Warfare series. It can be played as a stand-alone game, or in the middle of other games in the series, when a duel occurs (instead of the even simpler original rules).

The players simultaneously choose what they do in their turn, reveal it and then fate cards decide the result.

Name: The Universal Fantasy Supplement
Description:
A 32 page booklet for adding fantasy elements such as magic users and their spells and various monsters and their special abilities to your existing set of miniatures rules. The inspiration comes from the popular literature of the time with an emphasis on the classic thematic elements.

There are three different types of magic users to add to your army:  Druids, Shamans, and Sorcerers.  Each gets 10 spell points to chose from the 25 available spells (cost 1-4 points each) but is limited thematically to what they may chose.  Adding a magic user to your army is expensive however, costing roughly the same point value as a Dragon, Giant, or a Commanding General.

Twenty different classic monsters are created for your army by following a simple template system.  Here is an example of how to get stats for a goblin character by making conversions to your normal miniatures rules:

Goblins:
Fight as:  Light, medium or light-medium infantry only.
Movement:  As designated troop type.
Frontage:  As designated troop type.
Special:  Like Orcs, Goblins loose one morale grade for reaction test purposes in bright sunlight.
Limits:  No more than one Goblin unit in an army may be designated as elite.  Goblins may never be classed as regular troops.

(User Summary)

Name: Dopedeal Zonder Grenzen
Description:
Players have to buy and sell drugs around the world.
At the start of the game each player gets 15,000 euro. The player throws a die and moves along the board. The board displays different countries.
Players can buy or sell drugs where they land with their pawn. Some places are cheaper than others to buy weed.
at some spaces a player gets a 'Kontaktkaart'.  With these cards a player gets benefits like free travelling to another country.
When a player has earned 2,000,000 euro, he/she wins the game.

Name: Det Store Norske Familiespillet
Description:
The Great Norwegian Family Game is a game for the entire family, with questions in two grades of difficulty. A fairly close relative of Trivial Pursuit, the questions come from the Great Norwegian Encyclopedia.

The total of 6200 questions are divided across eight subjects, and offer challenge to any player.

Name: Age of Steam Expansion: California Gold Rush & Underground Railroad
Description:
This are two full size, full color mounted maps that fold to a size that fits in both the Steam and Age of Steam boxes. At first glance, both have similar rules changes: an option to forsake delivery of goods cubes or an increase of locomotive and replace it with a special function that will be key to winning the game. But the differences between the maps and how they are played are substantial.

California Gold Rush takes place in the mid 1800’s in Central California. Pockets of gold have been found, and you need to lay claim to the mines before your opponents. To do so you need to build railroads out to the gold mines and pick up the gold. The mechanics are modified slightly during the delivery phase: you always have the option of picking up any available gold cube wherever your track has been laid instead of delivering a regular good cube or increasing your locomotive. At the end of the game, each of the gold cubes increases your income (VPs in Steam) by 5. California Gold Rush is for 3-6 players.

Underground Railroad takes place in the years leading up to the civil war all across the Eastern United States. During the goods delivery phase, players may opt to move slaves north to a free city instead of delivering a goods cube or increasing their locomotive. They don’t receive any income for doing so. The winner is determined by who frees the most slaves...as long as they don’t go bankrupt before the end of the game.  Underground Railroad is for 3-5 players.

The 2010 Essen Aos/Steam map pack from Bezier Games features 7 new maps, including 6 mounted ones on 3 double-sided expansions. These maps can be preordered from Bezier Games and will ship in October 2010. The “bonus” 7th map is only available through preorders.

Name: HeroQuest: Running the Gauntlet
Description:
This is a Solo Quest for a Wizard.

Description in the book:
This is a HeroQuest adventure for which you will require the HeroQuest board game. You will need a GamesMaster and one player. Rules are the same as for any HeroQuest game, but the adventure has one difference: it is only for a Wizard.

Additional note:
This Solo Adventure was published in the book: The Screaming Spectre.
The book has 3 parts:
- Story to read
- Solo Adventure for Heroquest Bordgame
- Gamebook Soloadventure

Name: Heroquest: A Growl of Thunder
Description:
A Solitaire Quest for a Barbarian.

Description from the book:
This is a HeroQuest adventure for which you will require the HeroQuest board game. You will need a Gamesmaster and just one player. Rules are the same as for any HeroQuest game, but the adventure has one difference: it is only for a Barbarian.

Additional note:
This Solo Adventure was published in the book: The Tyrant's Tomb.
The book has 3 parts:
- Story to read
- Solo Adventure for Heroquest Boardgame
- Gamebook Soloadventure

Name: Crouch Touch Engage Rugby
Description:
Touch, Crouch, Engage Rugby is an easy to learn replay game on rugby, featuring complete statistical data for all the Five Nations and Six Nations tournaments from 1980 till 2010.
Each match is resolved with a few dice rolls and you may able to replay an entire tournament in fifteen minutes!!
It uses a derivation of the system premiered in Dream to end all dreams: World Cup Soccer, more developed to take in account the peculiar key aspects of rugby.
First step is to compare the Attack class of the first team against the Defense class of the opponent (both indicated by a letter on the data sheet for the tournament chosen). Calculate the difference between the higher class and the inferior, divide by two the result (rounding up toward the inferior value) and take this number as a column shift from the higher value toward the inferior value (see the example below, for a clearer explanation). Now, roll 2 6-sided die on the "Tries Table" to see how many tries that team has scored in the match. Then, check the "conversion percentage" of that team and roll a percentage dice (ie. two 10-sided dice, reading one of them as "tens") for each try scored: if the roll is inside the percentage value, the try is succesfully converted (add two points to team's score); otherwise, conversion kick is failed. Then, check the "Three points" value of the team to see how many penalty kicks/drops have been scored during the match. Roll 1 10-sided die on the correct column of the "3-points Table", multiply by 3 the number obtained and add that result to the points scored by that team to reach its total for the match. Repeat this procedure for the opposing team and you will get the final result of the match.

A separate expansion set contains data for all the World Cup and the Tri Nations tournaments

Name: Alchemy
Description:
A fast two-player abstract strategy stacking game with a theme and a twist

(Designer’s note: Alchemy was created as a simple game to thank the gamer community and fans of Symbol. Alchemy is played with one player’s basic set of pieces from Symbol, and thus provides a clever way to determine first player for a game of Symbol or can be played as a separate stand alone game for those who want a quick match that is easy to learn, almost impossible to solve, fun, and mathematically very interesting; though a new and unique game, Alchemy shares some ideas and mechanics with other stacking strategy games and members of the NIM family of games.)

The players represent dueling alchemists trying to make chemical reactions with the Aristotelian elements (earth, water, air, fire), and a fifth, unstable element of destruction.  Alchemists want to create gold, but they never could figure out how to create gold, so instead the players are fighting over a single gold coin by alternating turns making new combinations of elements.  When on a player’s turn no new combinations are possible, that player loses the round.  The first player to win two rounds in a row wins the game.

Name: S. Jorge Trophy
Description:
This game is about the Castle of S. Jorge, a castle that is in the centre of Lisbon and has more than 1.000 years of history.

In this long history, the Castle has had several masters and has known all kind of characters. From the iron age Chief to the last King of Portugal, from the Roman Governor to the Arabic Sultan, from Kings to Scientists, from Navigators to Middle Age Writers, all of these have marked their presence in the Castle and their history is vivid in our memories still today.

In this game, 12 of the most prominent characters that have lived in the Castle dispute a tournament. This tournament happens only each 1.000 years, and the winner will reign over the Castle for the next 1.000 years.

To win this tournament, each character must walk around the board paths and some secret passages, and collect and preserve 3 S. Jorge Trophies. But be careful with the false trophies, they weight on you and slow you down.

You also have to be aware of other characters: if they encounter you, they may steal your trophies. Or you may steal theirs. Or you may discard some of your "non-valid" trophies on their back. Or the opposite. Anyway, something may happen.

And, of course, you have a special ability. Something that only you can do. How to take the most of it, that's your job.

Name: Tiddlycricket
Description:
This is, as the name suggests, a game that is a combination of cricket and tiddlywinks.

Contents:
Minature cricket bat
Minature cricket stumps
Felt bowling crease
1 large and 4 small winks

The wicket is set up on a table with a mat for the bowler's crease 22 inches away. The batsman holds the bat in front of the wicket, and the bowler 'bowls' by flicking a small wink with the big one. The batsman tries to hit the wink with the bat, and there are rules for runs scored and some ways to get out.

Name: Περσικοί Πόλεμοι Μολών Λαβέ
Description:
ΠερσικοÎ¯ ΠÏŒλεμοι is a game depicting the war between the Persian Empire and Ancient Greece. The players take the roles of the Persian and Greek armies and fight for the control of key areas in a map depicting Greece during that period.

The game includes 4 scenarios for the players to play, each of them based on actual historic events. Each scenario lasts 14 rounds with each round representing a year between 492 BC and 479 BC. Most of the scenarios require one of the two sides to have control of some specific areas at the end of the last round.

The game also includes an educational leaflet with a brief description of the actual events that took place during that period and on which the scenarios are based.

Components:

     1 Gameboard 52x46cm (Ancient Greece - Minor Asia)
     9 Cards of yearly event
     1 Notepad (Chronology 492-479bc)
     92 Plastic pawns 
     12 Plastic flags
     1 Special 6sided dice (0,1,1,2,2,3)
     Historical and educational leaflet
     Rulles 


Description in Greek, taken from the game's back cover:

Τα 2/3 του παγκÏŒσμιου πληθυσμοÏ, του τÏŒτε γνωστοÏ κÏŒσμου, ζοÏσε και πÎ­θαινε, υπÏŒ την εξουσÎ¯α της δυναστεÎ¯ας των ΑχαιμενιδÏŽν. Name: What's That Sound?
Description:
Publisher blurb on side of the box:  Can you tell the difference between teeth being brushed and wood being sawed?  The first person to figure out which lotto board picture matches the sound heard on the cassette tape wins!  WHAT THAT SOUND? stimulates a child's imagination and develops important listening, matching and memorization skills.

DIRECTIONS: The cassette tape features 36 sounds in four different sequences.  You may start the game at any point on either side of the tape.  Varying the starting point will give you a different game each time.  As you identify each sound, simply cover the matching picture with a token.  Parents may want to introduce this game or play it with younger children by helping them to name and identify each picture.  Language skills and vocabulary will be expanded and children will then be able to further increase their knowledge and skills by playing as outline above.

Name: Het Grote Belgiëspel
Description: Travel the ten provinces of Belgium answering trivia questions about the history, geography and organisational structures of the country. Players gain fries (Belgian, of course) by answering questions correctly. The first player to reach the Royal palace in Brussels with 20 or more fries, wins the game.

Name: Castles, Cogs & Chevauchees
Description:
Three rules sets covering sieges, navies, and campaigns in skirmish level combat.  Designed for use with Knights & Knaves and adaptable to other skirmish level rules. 36 pages.  (Book Cover)

"Castles" - rules for conducting sieges in your campaign.  Thirteen pages covering the three types of sieges you can mount: Blockade, Bombardment, or Assault.  Sieges are conducted on a weekly basis and both the attacker and defender must manage their armies and resources to be successful.

"Cogs" - rules for handling ship to ship engagements.  Two pages of rules covering simple boat movement, grappling, and skirmishing on board the vessels.

"Chevauchees" - rules for conducting a full campaign.  Fourteen pages of economic rules including how to acquire and spend resources, dramatic events, and how to set up multiple detailed and linked skirmishes for the campaign including using the rules from the Castles and Cogs sections.

Name: Now What? Senseless Solutions to Strange Situations
Description: Now What? is a storytelling party game. Players read out strange Dilemmas and then take turns telling a story to solve the dilemma using the object cards laid out for everyone to see. Players who come up with the most unique stories score points.

Name: Nestortiles
Description:
Nestortiles is the first game system published by NESTORGAMES.

Nestortiles are interlocking foam panels in different colors, numbered like dice or dominoes, with 1 to 6 pips on each. They can be used to play many games.

You can use them as tiles, creating flat maps like dungeons, or assemble them three-dimensionally to create custom six-sided dice. These dice can range from the standard D6 numbered 1 to 6 in one color to any D6 you can imagine, by mixing colors and numbers.

For example, you can create a die like this: Green 1 - Green 5 - Blue 1 - Red 4 - Yellow 6 - Yellow 6.

There are 2 types of Nestortiles:

A-Type: The interlocking teeth are short, so the edges of the assembled dice are flush, suitable for making a single die, for example.

B-Type: The interlocking teeth are about double in length, allowing you to connect multiple tiles or dice in order to create more complex 3D structures.

Moreover, you can customize the tiles by drawing on their backs with a permanent marker or by adding stickers, and create your own designs!

Nestortiles are sold in packs of 60 tiles in 10 colors, (6 tiles per color, numbered 1 to 6), and can only be purchased on the nestorgames site.

Name: Warheads Medieval Tales
Description:
Warheads: Medieval Tales is tabletop miniatures wargame with some role-playing elements, set in a comical and mythical medieval England.

As well as new scenarios and characters each edition of the Warheads Magazine delivers large sections of narrative and high quality artwork.

Players control one of two heroes and their followers. Every character in the game has their own statistics, skills and narrative which makes them unique. Over the course of the series characters and parties grow and evolve based on the decisions that players make as well as an experience and equipment based system for customization.

Rules are introduced a little at a time in a tutorial style, with just enough presented initially to play the first scenario. Depth is added by each subsequent scenario with range and cover rules presented in the second scenario of issue one before rules for magic are introduced for the third and final scenario of the first book. The game uses a dice based system for determining events such as combat.

The Warheads: Medieval Tales saga is to be delivered over 6 magazine installments, each magazine launched with two accompanying miniature box sets containing between 4-8 unpainted 28mm metal miniatures.

From publishers Website:

Warheads: Medieval Tales is a fast and fun two player tabletop game for players of all ages and abilities. Every two months we'll release a full-colour, lavishly illustrated magazine in which you get to tell the story of Hugo of Deangard and his bitter rival Gui le Batard, as they gather followers to fight each other and go on amazing quests. Over the course of six issues the story unfolds with you in charge of the characters' destinies and development.

Each magazine contains all the rules you need to play the battles and characters contained in it and is accompanied by two boxed sets of uniquely-styled Warheads gaming miniatures.

The rules are fast and easy to learn, and they build over the lifetime of the game, so you don't have to learn everything before you start. Warheads: Medieval Tales blends the best of story driven role-playing and tabletop wargaming

Name: Steam Expansion: Sicily & Malta
Description: Sicily & Malta is a Steam map for 2 players.

Name: Pyramids and Flags
Description:
Pyramids and Flags is a game for 2 to 4 players with one Rainbow and one Xeno set of Treehouse pyramids to play it. Out of these pyramids, players put together flags of specific countries from all over the world. Apart from the pyramids and the pack of 36 goal cards, you do not need anything else.

Move a pyramid to create a flag!

Complete rules are available at the author's website, and at the Icehouse Wiki.

Name: European War
Description:
Introducing the Game

The successor to the Austrian throne survived Sarajevo assassination and became in 1916 the Emperor Franz Ferdinand. Just a few years passed and in Europe it simmer again!

At the outbreak of the war, Europe is divided into five blocks, which are: Britain and its Allies, the Russian Empire, France and its Allies, Ottoman Empire and Central Powers.

The game uses a modified original map of Europe, close to the state in 1914, but reflecting the development of an imaginary continent.

Key imaginary historical events before the war include the following:

Britain: In the twenties Britain got into serious conflicts with the Tsarist Russia and left the Triple Entente. From the thirties there was a gradual democratization in the colonies. Scandinavian countries see in the UK its natural protector against expanding Russia and Germany. After the riots in the Iberian Peninsula, Gibraltar outpost spreads to Andalusia and Portugal.

The Russian Empire: in the late twenties hit the Russian Empire its limits in far Asia. The Grand Duchy of Finland used the growing tension between Russia and Britain to escape from the Russia in early thirties. The abdication of a liberal the Tsar and the emergence new militant faction to power jump-started a new phase of armaments in Europe.

France: After the failed assassination in Sarajevo, it was France who saved by its diplomatic activity the European peace. In the thirties, France tried to create a large Mediterranean Union. South of the Apennine peninsula and Balkan were hit by neoislamic expansion of the Ottoman Empire and the French plan foiled. Against the traditional enemy - Germany - has France built an extensive Maginot Line.

Central Powers: Emperor Franz Ferdinand poured into crusty Austro-Hungarian veins new blood. In early twenties he federalized and modernized Austro-Hungary and in the thirties gradually agreed to trade and customs union with imperial Germany. The economic and military power of Central Powers long dampen expansionary ambitions of neighboring states. The Germans built along the lines with France its own line of defense - Siegfried Line.

The Ottoman Empire: the rapid modernization of the Ottoman Empire, launched by the world's thirst for oil, awoke southeast Europe to a new prosperity. Once Europe's sick man rallied by endless supply of black gold. In the late twenties, after a series of smaller conflicts, Ottomans returned to the southern Balkans and Islamic radicalization in the thirties dominate in large areas of northern Africa and even in southern Italy.

Each of the Powers thinks only of itself and just like you wants to be the best and win over all. Powers also conclude mutually beneficial agreements, lead diplomatic negotiations to form a military alliances, and so even you can not ignore this part of the game. Occupy all three fields of one power or help push your arch-enemy of its territory. This is not "Ludo", this is "The War."

Goal of the game

Your task is to occupy the entire territory of any other power (three fields of one color), while keeping on your own territory at least one pyramid.

You also win when your arch enemy loses his last piece from his own territory. His loss is your victory.

Name: De Binnenvaart
Description:
In this game each player an enterprising skipper. Everyone starts with one small ship and a capital. You can earn money with your ship cargo between the inland transport.
With the money you earned, you could buy a larger type of ship and 
The first player which collected the agreed amount in cash, is the winner.

Name: Baltimore & Ohio: Maine Lumber Expansion
Description:
Baltimore & Ohio: Maine Lumber Expansion is the smallest expansion Winsome has ever produced, but it has a big effect on the base game. 
This is part of Winsome's Essen 2010 set.
Winsome Games' 2010 Essen Set

Name: Age of Steam Expansion: Poland
Description:
Age of Steam: Poland is part of Winsome's Essen 2010 set. 
Winsome Games' 2010 Essen Set

This expansion includes a map of Poland in two sections and a sheet of special rules.

If you ordered the Essen Set from Winsome and did not get your sheet of special rules, please send an email to winsome@fyi.net and we will mail them to you. Sorry about the Snafu!
